verses.verse: (He praiseth the Lord with great affection and humility for his kingdom restored, and for his victories obtained.5 Demanding help, and the destruction of the wicked,9 Promising to acknowledge the same with songs of praises,15 And declareth wherein the felicity of any people consisteth. ) Blessed be the Lord my strength, which teacheth mine hands to fight, and my fingers to battle.

He is my goodness and my fortress, my tower and (Hebrew, my deliverer unto me: for the Prophet cannot satisfy himself with any words.) my deliverer, my shield and in him I trust, (He confesseth that neither by his own authority, power or policy his kingdom was quiet, but by the secret grace of God.) which subdueth my people under me.

Lord, what is man that thou (To give unto God just praise, is to confess ourselves to be unworthy of so excellent benefits, and that he bestoweth them upon us of his free mercy.) regardest him! or the son of man that thou thinkest upon him?
Man is like to vanity; his days are like a shadow that vanisheth.
(He desireth God to continue his graces, and to send help for the present necessity.) Bow thine heavens, O Lord, and come down; touch the mountains, and they shall smoke.

(By these manner of speeches he showeth that all the lets in the world cannot hinder God’s power, which he apprehended by faith.) Cast forth the lightning and scatter them; shoot out thine arrows and consume them.

Send thine hand from above: deliver me, and take me out of the great (That is, deliver me from the tumults of them that should be my people, but are corrupt in their judgment and enterprises, as though they were strangers.) waters, and from the hand of strangers,
Whose mouth talketh vanity, and their right hand is a right hand (For though they shake hands, yet they keep not promise.) of falsehood.
I will sing a (That is, a rare and excellent song, as thy great benefits deserve.) new song unto thee, O God, and sing unto thee upon a viol, and an instrument of ten strings.

It is he that giveth deliverance unto kings, and rescueth David his (Though wicked kings be called God’s servants, as Cyrus, Isa. 45:1, forasmuch as he useth them to execute his judgments: yet David because of God’s promise, and they that rule godly, are properly so called, because they serve not their own affections, but set forth God’s glory.) servant from the hurtful sword.
Rescue me, and deliver me from the hand of strangers, whose mouth talketh vanity, and their right hand is a right hand of falsehood:

(He desireth God to continue his benefits toward his people, counting the procreation of children and their good education among the chiefest of God’s benefits.) That our sons may be as the plants growing up in their youth, and our daughters as the corner stones, graven after the similitude of a palace:

That our (That the very corners of our houses may be full of store for the great abundance of thy blessings.) corners may be full and abounding with divers sorts, and that our sheep may bring forth thousands and ten thousand in our streets.

That our (He attributeth not only the great commodities, but even the least also to God’s favor.) oxen may be strong to labor; that there be none invasion, nor going out, nor no crying in our streets.
Blessed are the people, that be (And if God give not to all his children all these blessings, yet he recompenseth them with better things.) so, yea blessed are the people whose God is the Lord.
